sn9.1:4.2: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn9.1:4.3: Now at that time that mendicant, during their day’s meditation, was thinking bad, unskilful thoughts to do with the lay life.
sn9.1:4.4: The deity haunting that forest had compassion for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up,
sn9.1:5.2: yet your mind wanders off to outward things.
sn9.1:5.3: As a person, you should dispel the desire for people.
sn9.1:5.4: Then you’ll be happy, free of greed.
sn9.1:6.2: let us remind you of the way of the good.
sn9.1:6.3: The dusty abyss is so hard to cross;
sn9.1:6.4: don’t let sensual dust drag you down.
sn9.1:7.1: Just as a bird strewn with dirt
sn9.1:7.2: sheds that clingy dust with a shake;
sn9.1:7.3: so too, an energetic, mindful mendicant
sn9.1:7.4: sheds that clingy dust with a shake.”
sn9.1:8.1: Stirred up by that deity, that mendicant came to their senses.
